verses.text: God takes His stand in the assembly of the mighty; He judges among the gods.
verses.comment: This verse depicts God presiding over a divine council, judging among those called 'gods'—likely human judges or rulers, but possibly angelic beings. Jesus references this in John 10:34, indicating a deeper spiritual reality and foreshadowing His authority to judge.

verses.text: How long will you judge unjustly and show favor to the wicked? Selah
verses.comment: God rebukes the judges for their injustice and partiality to the wicked. 'Selah' invites reflection on the seriousness of corruption among leaders tasked with God's justice.

verses.text: Defend the weak and the orphan; uphold the rights of the afflicted and the needy.
verses.comment: A call to defend society's vulnerable reflects God's concern for justice and care for the oppressed. True faith requires action toward justice for the defenseless, prefiguring later New Testament teachings on love and works (see James 1:27).

verses.text: Rescue the poor and needy; deliver them from the hand of the wicked.
verses.comment: Leaders are commanded to actively rescue those in danger, symbolizing God’s own redemptive acts. There is an allusion here to salvation and deliverance, themes fulfilled in Christ’s saving mission.

verses.text: They neither know nor understand; they walk about in darkness. All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
verses.comment: Because unjust rulers are ignorant of God’s ways, moral order collapses. This hints at the need for divinely guided authority to uphold truth and justice.

verses.text: I said, 'You are gods, and all of you are sons of the Most High.'
verses.comment: God bestowed honor and responsibility on the judges, calling them 'gods' in reference to their office and authority. Jesus cites this verse in John 10:34 to clarify the distinction between those appointed by God and His own divine Sonship.

verses.text: But you will die like men, and fall like any of the princes.
verses.comment: Although given high authority, the unjust will face mortal judgment for their failures. This verse underscores both human frailty and the need for faithfulness to divine calling.

verses.text: Rise up, O God, judge the earth! For You shall inherit all nations.
verses.comment: The Psalmist prays for God’s ultimate judgment and rule over all nations—a prophecy fulfilled in Christ’s universal kingship (see Rev. 11:15). The expectation is for God’s just reign to be established on earth and among all peoples, inviting the whole world into the fullness of divine worship and unity.
